text: President Obama has gained few friends
on Wall Street for calling bankers fat
cats but he may not be losing his
deep-pocketed supporters that fast just
yet hello my name is Evelyn Rusli I'm a
reporter with DealBook for the New York
Times joining us today is andrew ross
sorkin he's the editor of deal book
thanks for joining us Andrea good
morning so in this week's column you
talked about how Wall Street is showing
some reluctance to commit to Obama but
they may not be deserting him in mascot
right well you know I think there's this
the conventional wisdom is somehow that
wall street has completely turned its
back on Obama that they're not
supporting him they're not giving him
money they're not doing anything last
week there was a big dinner at Danielle
cost over 38,000 dollars and they packed
the room so there's one element which is
their people who are doing it publicly
but even more importantly I think
privately despite all of the rhetoric
there is a sense that even though people
aren't necessarily giving him money so
publicly and they don't necessarily want
to be seen as supporting him given what
he's been saying that privately they may
ultimately turn turn around and vote for
him well what about some of his previous
backers like Lloyd Blankfein Jamie Dimon
who weren't at the dinner right well I
think that's what that people looked at
the dinner and said yo where are the big
names what's going on here and you know
in this environment there's two issues
one is that many of the CEOs themselves
as I said before don't want to be put in
a position where they're looking like
they're supporting somebody who's
obviously coming down on their
businesses in terms of financial reform
and everything else the other side which
is almost ironic is that the the
campaign isn't actually pushing some of
the biggest names to show up with these
events because the idea that you know
Obama and Lloyd Blankfein are going to
be in a you know a photo spread together
as well as one banker said to me you
know isn't good for either of them and
and so there's sort of another reality
to the story but there is some tension
between Wall Street and Obama right how
do you read the pulse today where would
you say you know Wall Street is
generally speaking are they happy with
Obama I think they're privately okay
with Obama I think there's one thing to
come out and say we support you at the
same time that you're putting that
you're trying to push back on capital
requirements and all the
other financial reform measures it's
another thing to say is it you know
internally I think they're saying it
isn't it hasn't been nearly as bad as
you know we might have it might have
been yeah and you mentioned that you
know of the political candidates right
now the field there's not too many that
are kind of absorbing the support that
Obama would have gotten right so so how
will this shake out in the next election
cycle well look Wall Street likes to
make its bets and likes to hedge its
bets so what we might not be seeing
people jump in to support people this
early in the race we're going to find
out who the Republican candidate is if
it's Mitt Romney I think that's somebody
The Wall Street can ultimately live with
you know if it's michelle bachman i
think that's actually going to be a much
tougher sell and you might see a lot
more support for obama so ultimately i
think you're going to see a lot of money
come into this campaign and you're going
to see people making multiple bets
because as they say in the business they
like to hedge their bets well thank you
so much Andrew really appreciate it once
again my guest today is an Andrew Sorkin
he's the editor DealBook I'm Evelyn
Rusli with DealBook for the New York
